column2: Holmes entered the Dane Law School at Cambridge. He did not feel at all sure
column4: that he wished to be a lawyer
column5: and at the end of a year he had so far lost interest in his studies that he gave them up. As the physician's calling seemed much more to his liking
column6: he took two courses of study in a private school of medicine. This preparation was not
column8: sufficient to fit him for a larger practice
column9: so a trip to Europe where he could study under the great professors of the School of Medicine at Paris became necessary. Accordingly
column12: provided him with the required means
column13: and he set sail from New York in the spring of 1833.During the two years spent abroad
column14: Holmes gave himself up wholly to his chosen study. "I am more and more attached every day to the study of my profession.... I am occupied from morning to night
column15: and as every one is happy when he is occupied
column16: I enjoy myself as much as I could wish
